I think @jtulach would be a better reviewer for this.

A few comments:
-not clear to me what exactly runs out of memory (added a comment in that sense to the Jira bug)
-not clear if the nodes that are currently being deleted are actually removed from the selection model? (Since with this patch, they are no longed added to remSel.)
-related to that - do tests pass (and, ideally, is there a test verifying the removed nodes are properly removed from the selection)?
-is there a chance to create a test for this?
@matthiasblaesing Thank you! I'll give it a try later.

I'm not sure if I'm happy with this changeset. The warnings are there for a reason, mechanical replacement with the most open generic, plasters over these warnings. This raises the question why they exist in the first place.
Merged via https://github.com/apache/netbeans/commit/3498ed8164c3d82c390dd4dad477630b43c2b827 without the API change.
Change looks reasonable and I assume, that it was manually tested. Merging. Thank you.

sry to ask, has this change also a impact on 'Test File'? Currently if I you it on a `*Test` file it will use surefire to run the test cases and all is fine, but if I use it in a `*IT` file it will also use surefire, and so the configuration for failsafe will not be used and bad thinks happens ... next nice to have will be execution integrationtests should also run plugins in pre- and post-integrationtest-phase e.g. start stop some external stuff?

@toepi no it does not change the GUI integration for running test. That was out of scope for this. For running post/pre integration things: This hooks into the maven build machine, so if maven would do it, netbeans will do it.

@branscha It looks like the problem is that nbm-maven-plugin needs to be updated and built with the new app.conf file. @ebarboni Can you confirm this?
Looks sane - thank you.
Looks good to me. Thank you.
Looks good to me.
I get nervous if people catch `Throwable`, but I think in this case its ok. Merging. Thank you.
I can understand why you check for the mysql driver, but without the driver none of the tests is run - so why pretend different? I would not add this module to the test list.

Could you please describe what you are fixing and how it is archived? I see that before your change I see failures and afterwards they are gone, but the why is missing. The same is true for the `ide/versioning.core` module. Thank you.

@matthiasblaesing I removed the module from the test list. 
My idea is prepare this module to permit execute the `ant test` command for all modules and this doesn't fail if the mysql driver isn't present.
There doesn't seem to be anything here?!  Please open a JIRA ticket or email the dev@ list and explain what you're trying to achieve.

@matthiasblaesing I cancelled this pull request in favour of this other: #1445

Uh, I didn't know about this plugin - I change the code here so that it can (/is) suppressed when that module is installed.

I would also be awesome if that module could be contributed here!

Thanks for the comment!

I understand and mostly agree with your assessment about this change. Let's take this piece of code for discussion before my change:

`Class clazz = cl.loadClass("org.jboss.as.controller.client.helpers.Operations");`

So what Netbeans is doing is loading a Class and removing the type information by setting it to a raw type. 

My change simply maintains that type information. I know it's a pretty generic statement. But, the Java Language Standard, sec. 4.8 says the following:

> The use of raw types is allowed only as a concession to compatibility of legacy code. The use of raw types in code written after the introduction of generics into the Java programming language is strongly discouraged. It is possible that future versions of the Java programming language will disallow the use of raw types. 

Why does this code exist? My rookie opinion is this code is "old" and therefore was never designed to work with generics in the first place. 

Also, given the limited resources I'm not sure things like this will ever be fixed properly. There are simply more pressing needs.

As we fix more of these raw type errors, it should make us more diligent in terms of creating better code.

Hi @peedeeboy,

I have fixed the ergonomics error, May you test the PR again with the latest commit?
@oyarzun @ebarboni Yes that seems to be the case. I will try to find the correct location to mention the issue. Thanks for helping out.

@branscha yes, I noticed this issue too while testing Maven post-release, and commented "somewhere" - I think on a related JIRA ticket.  There are a few issues with Maven support for Apache releases that we can hopefully get fixed in 11.2.

In answer to your wider question about how fixes hit production - anything in master on the release date is in the release.

@branscha FYI, the current workaround would be to add `etcConfFile` to your pom.

```xml
<configuration>
     <etcConfFile>src/main/resources/my.conf</etcConfFile>
</configuration>
```

See Geertjan's blog entry https://blogs.oracle.com/geertjan/nimbus-look-and-feel-for-maven-based-netbeans-rcp-applications

This pull request is superseded by [pull request 1446](https://github.com/apache/netbeans/pull/1446) which addresses the issues here, approaching the problem from a completely different direction.
@naitsirch lots of people will not be using the installer - better it's handled elsewhere.

> Couldn't this configuration be integrated into the installer?

Do not assume everyone uses an installer.  It could be where there *is* an installer, but is completely unhelpful if you build it yourself, or install it with the OS package manager, or use a distro like Gentoo where the "package manager" compiles everything from source with optimizations for your machine.

For the folks mentioning `-J-Dswing.aatext=true` and `-J-Dawt.useSystemAAFontSettings=lcd`:

 * `-J-Dswing.aatext=true` - Has no effect on the JDK's swing classes since JDK 6, but is used by NetBeans in a few places[1].  In most (all?) cases, with another patch I recently submitted, `useSystemAAFontSettings` will be preferentially used if present
 * `-J-Dawt.useSystemAAFontSettings=lcd` - There are actually several options for this [documented here](https://docs.oracle.com/javase/7/docs/technotes/guides/2d/flags.html) - the UI this patch adds will show the user each one and let them choose which looks best (`lcd` is usually decent but frequently there are better choices for a specific monitor, although if you have multiple monitors it forces you to choose one that may be right for one and wrong for the other)

> [1] Places swing.aatext is used:
> ide/editor.completion/src/org/netbeans/modules/editor/completion/PatchedHtmlRenderer.java - this is a fork of org.openide.awt.HtmlRenderer which should get merged with it and deleted
> ide/editor.settings.storage/src/org/netbeans/modules/editor/settings/storage/fontscolors/CompositeFCS.java - tries to get hints right within the font color settings options window and perhaps elsewhere - does not look as if it also checks LCD hints
> ide/editor/lib/src/org/netbeans/modules/editor/lib/EditorRenderingHints.java - looks like a copy/paste of the code from CompositeFCS
> ide/gsf.testrunner.ui/src/org/netbeans/modules/gsf/testrunner/ui/output/OutputView.java - has my name as co-author but I don't recall it. Looks like a fork of something from core.output2, maybe ExtPlainView
> ide/team.commons/src/org/netbeans/modules/bugtracking/commons/LinkButton.java
> ide/versioning.util/src/org/netbeans/modules/versioning/history/LinkButton.java - these two both look like copy/pastes of the same class. Handles lcd correctly
> nb/welcome/src/org/netbeans/modules/welcome/content/Utils.java - ensures antialiasing the welcome screen 
> platform/core.output2/src/org/netbeans/core/output2/ExtPlainView.java - output window antialiasing, handles lcd correctly
> platform/core.output2/src/org/netbeans/core/output2/WrappedTextView.java - wrapped text view for the output window, handles lcd correctly
> platform/o.n.core/src/org/netbeans/beaninfo/editors/ColorEditor.java - color editor for beaninfo, probably completely unused these days
> platform/o.n.core/src/org/netbeans/beaninfo/editors/FontEditor.java - ditto - old beaninfo editor
> platform/o.n.swing.tabcontrol/src/org/netbeans/swing/tabcontrol/plaf/ColorUtil.java - handles rendering hints for editor tabs
> platform/openide.awt/src/org/openide/awt/HtmlLabelUI.java - wraps HtmlRenderer (used by explorer views and much more - a much higher performance html renderer than Swing's

I believe the reason why this was introduced is that for modular J2SE projects, the copying does not work (specifically, copying of module path is not supported, AFAIK). It might still be OK, but possibly a better solution would be to base the decision on module-info:
https://github.com/apache/netbeans/pull/1469

It is not completely correct, as a project without module-info can still depend on module on the module path (which is then not copied, and the simple java -jar would not work anyway), but I think that is an acceptable trouble, as such projects are likely to be very rare.
@vieiro aside from flexibility to redirect, the other reason for keeping links inbound from the IDE under `/nb/` was to allow for the option of tracking requests separately.

Perhaps this additional info found at [https://stackoverflow.com/questions/55994732/netbeans-11-does-not-copy-libs-into-dist-folder](url) is important:
Setting do.mkdist=true in the nbproject/private/private.properties file also solves the problem
Regards
OK, I will close this one and merge https://github.com/apache/netbeans/pull/1469.
